data.title: Warburg, pvt equity firm buy Dutch cable co for $2.6bn
data.meta_description: Private equity firms Cinven and Warburg Pincus have agreed to buy Dutch cable operator Casema for $2.6bn, one of the Casema owners.
data.text:
Synopsis

Private equity firms Cinven and Warburg Pincus have agreed to buy Dutch cable operator Casema for $2.6bn, one of the Casema owners.

AMSTERDAM: Private equity firms Cinven and Warburg Pincus have agreed to buy Dutch cable operator Casema for e2.1bn ($2.6bn), one of the Casema owners, the Carlyle Group, said on Tuesday.

Casema, which is jointly owned by private equity firms Providence Equity Partners, Carlyle Group and GMT Communications Partners, is the Netherlands’ third-largest cable operator.

The transaction, which is expected to close in the second half of ‘06, is subject to regulatory approvals. Casema serves about 1.3m subscribers in the central and south-western regions of the Netherlands.

Private equity firms have been acquiring European cable firms over the past few years as consumers across the continent increasingly embrace multi-channel digital TV, high-speed broadband and internet-based telephone services.

Other bidders for Casema included BC Partners, Macquarie Bank and Liberty Global’s UPC Netherlands, according to media reports. Providence Equity Partners, Carlyle Group and GMT Communications Partners, together acquired Casema for e665m in ‘03 from France Telecom. They have invested about e250m since then in upgrading the network.

Providence and Carlyle each own 46% of Casema and GMT owns 8 %. Goldman Sachs International was the sole financial advisor. Among other recent deals, Warburg Pincus acquired rival Dutch operator Multikabel last year for 515m euros.

Cinven recently agreed to buy UPC France for 1.25m euros to gain control of nearly all of the country’s cable networks. Essent, the Netherlands’ second-largest cable operator, is also up for sale.
